adk.selectorswitch

Class SelectorDial

  • java.lang.Object
    • adk.selectorswitch.SelectorDial

  • class SelectorDial
extends java.lang.Object
    SelectorDial describes the dial used in a selector switch. This dial has different modes that can be selected by the user. This class stores the structural properties of the dial. Every selector switch has an instance of selector dial and every time the view of the switch is drawn onto the canvas, these structural details are queried from the selector dial.

    The structure of the dial is described here.

    The details stored include the radius of the dial, the number of modes in the dial, the color and paint used to draw each one of them, the angle at which each mode starts in the dial and the angle between two modes.

    • Constructor Detail

      • SelectorDial

        SelectorDial(android.content.Context context,
             int dialModeCount,
             java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> dialColors)
      throws IllegalSelectorException
        Constructs a selector dial and initialises its properties based on the given values.

        The properties initialised are :

        • dialModeCount
        • dialRadius
        • modeSweepingAngle
        • modeStartingAngles
        • dialColors: List generated from the int[] dialColors arg .
        • dialPaints: List generated from the dialColors .
        Parameters:
        context - Context: A context used to calculate the density of the screen for calculating dial's radius in pixels from DPs.
        dialModeCount - int: The total number of modes in the dial, which should be at least MIN_MODES and at most MAX_MODES.
        dialColors - int[]: Array specifies the color used for each mode in the dial.
        Throws:
        IllegalSelectorException - If dialModeCount is less than MIN_MODES or greater than MAX_MODES.
        See Also:
        SelectorUtil, SelectorUtil.arrayToList(int[]), SelectorUtil.generateDialPaints(int, List), SelectorUtil.getSweepingAngle(int), SelectorUtil.generateStartingAngles(int, float)

      • SelectorDial

        public SelectorDial(android.content.Context context,
                    int dialModeCount,
                    int startingColor,
                    int endingColor)
             throws IllegalSelectorException
        Similar to the first constructor; except here only the starting and the ending colors are needed. The remaining colors for the intermediate modes are generated by blending these 2 colors gradually from the starting to the ending color. This blending is done using the SelectorUtil.generateBlendingColors(int, int, int) static method.
        Parameters:
        context - Context: The context used to get the screen's density.
        dialModeCount - int: The number of modes in the dial.
        startingColor - int: The first mode's or the starting mode's color in the dial.
        endingColor - int: The last mode's or the ending mode's color in the dial.
        Throws:
        IllegalSelectorException
        See Also:
        SelectorUtil, SelectorUtil.arrayToList(int[]), SelectorUtil.generateBlendingColors(int, int, int), SelectorUtil.getSweepingAngle(int), SelectorUtil.generateStartingAngles(int, float)

    • Method Detail

      • initialiseDial

        private void initialiseDial(int dialModeCount)
                     throws IllegalSelectorException
        Initialises the dialModeCount, dialRadius, modeSweepingAngle and modeStartingAngles for the various modes in the dial.
        Parameters:
        dialModeCount - The number of modes in the selector switch's dial.
        Throws:
        IllegalSelectorException - If the number of modes is less than MIN_MODES or more than MAX_MODES.
        See Also:
        SelectorUtil.getSweepingAngle(int), SelectorUtil.generateStartingAngles(int, float), SelectorUtil.getPixelsFromDips(int, float)

      • setDialColors

        void setDialColors(java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> dialColors)
        Updates the dialColors of the dial and re-initialises dialPaints based on the new list of colors.
        Parameters:
        dialColors - New list of colors (Integers).
        See Also:
        SelectorUtil.generateDialPaints(int, List)

      • setDialColors

        void setDialColors(int startingColor,
                   int endingColor)
        Updates the dialColors of the dial and re-initialises dialPaints using the list of blended colors generated from the given two colors.
        Parameters:
        startingColor - Color to start blending from.
        endingColor - Color to end blending at.
        See Also:
        SelectorUtil.generateBlendingColors(int, int, int), SelectorUtil.generateDialPaints(int, List)

                  int color)
        Updates the color for a specified mode in the dial and re co
        Parameters:

        color - New color for the mode.
        See Also:

      • getDialModeCount

        int getDialModeCount()
        Returns dialModeCount : the number of modes in the dial.
        Returns:
        dialModeCount

      • setDialModeCount

        void setDialModeCount(int dialModeCount)
               throws IllegalSelectorException
        Updates the dialModeCount of the dial. If the new count is more than the current count, current starting and ending colors are used to generate the a list of blending colors to for the new set of intermediate modes. If the new count is less or equal to than the current count, the current dialColors list is replaced by its subset of a size equal to the new count. The method also updates the dialPaints, modeSweepingAngle and modeStartingAngles based on the new number of modes.

        Parameters:
        dialModeCount - New number of modes.
        Throws:
        IllegalSelectorException - If the new number of states less than MIN_MODES or greater than MAX_MODES.
        See Also:
        SelectorUtil.generateBlendingColors(int, int, int), SelectorUtil.getSweepingAngle(int), SelectorUtil.generateStartingAngles(int, float)

      • getModeSweepingAngle

        java.lang.Float getModeSweepingAngle()
        Returns the angle between two successive modes in the dial.
        Returns:
        modeSweepingAngle

      • getModeStartingAngle

        java.lang.Float getModeStartingAngle(int mode)
        Returns the starting angle of a particular mode in the dial. Useful while drawing the dial onto the switch's canvas.
        Parameters:
        mode - Index of the mode.
        Returns:
        startingAngle The starting angle for the mode at the given index.
